H0.text: The slow movement of tectonic plates caused many of these anaerobic bacteria—bacteria that can only live where oxygen is absent and were well adapted to life on Earth over 2 billion years ago—to become extinct.

H1.text: The varying temperatures of each season caused many bacteria that could only live where oxygen is not present and were well adapted to life on Earth over 2 billion years ago to become extinct.

H2.text: An increase in volcanic activity under the oceans caused many anaerobic bacteria—those that could only live where oxygen is absent and were well adapted to life on Earth over 2 billion years ago—to become extinct.

H3.text: An increase in the number of photosynthetic organisms caused many of the bacteria that could only live where oxygen was absent—bacteria well adapted to life on Earth for over 2 billion years—to become extinct.

A4.text: The appearance of highly reactive free oxygen, attributed to photosynthesis by cyanobacteria, may have caused the extinction/extirpation of many early organisms on Earth—mostly archaeal colonies that were well adapted to life over 2 billion years ago.
